clear error.definition: an error made by a judge in his or her findings of fact which is such that it leaves the reviewing court with the firm and definite conviction that a mistake has been made
clear error.note: A clear error may or may not warrant reversal.

fundamental error.definition: in this entry used esp. in criminal cases

harmless error.definition: an error that does not affect a substantial right or change the outcome of a trial and does not warrant reversal or other modification of the lower court's decision on appeal

invited error.definition: an error resulting from a party's own request for or encouragement of an action by the court
invited error.note: A party may not seek relief based on invited error that he or she has induced.

manifest error.definition: an error that is obvious and indisputable and that warrants reversal on appeal

plain error.definition: an obvious and prejudicial error that affects the substantial rights of the parties and that results or probably results in a miscarriage of justice
plain error.note: Plain error warrants reversal on appeal even in the absence of objection to the error at trial.

prejudicial error.definition: an error that affects or presumptively affects the outcome of a trial

reversible error.definition: a substantial and prejudicial error warranting reversal on appeal
